story.storybody:
A recent data was made public by the government-run National Aids Control Organization (NACO) after activist Chetan Kothari has revealed that in India nearly 2,234 contracted HIV cases were noticed after blood transfusions in the past 17 months alone.

The syndrome remains one of the significant challenges especially in low and middle income countries. Considering the fact that the Net State Domestic Product (NSDP) of Uttar Pradesh is counted as one of the poorest states in India, the highest number of HIV cases which is pure negligence on the officials' part makes the case very shocking.

As per the report:

1.   Out of 2,234 cases, 341 cases were found in Uttar Pradesh.

2.   Gujarat and Maharashtra ranked at 2nd and 3rd position with 292 and 276 cases, respectively, which is followed by Delhi with 264 cases. The organisation also believes that the data is just a small part of the whole scenario and the real numbers would be double or triple of the cases found

3.   As per the law, it is mandatory for all the hospitals to screen donors and the donated blood for HIV, Hepatitis B and C but looks like this isn't been happening.

Here is all you need to know to understand the syndrome and infection better:

1    HIV infection results in serious deterioration of the immune system.

2    Its infection can break down the body's ability to fight other infections and diseases.

3    The syndrome AIDS refers to the most advanced stages of HIV infection.

4    HIV can be transmitted through: unprotected sexual intercourse with an infected person; transfusions of HIV contaminated blood; sharing of contaminated needles, syringes or other instruments; the transmission between a mother and her baby during pregnancy, childbirth and breastfeeding.

5    To prevent HIV transmission: practice safe sexual practices such as using condoms; getting tested and treated for sexually transmitted infections; avoiding injecting drugs or using new and disposable needles or syringes; ensuring that any blood or blood products that is being donated to you has been tested for HIV.

6    In India, the highest HIV prevalence rates are found in Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka, Manipur, Mizoram, and Nagaland.

7    Manipur, Nagaland and Mizoram have the highest adult HIV prevalence in the country.

8    Although North-east is less populated, it has, in comparison to other Indian states, some 100,000 people living with this condition.

9    According to the World Health Organization, HIV/AIDS remains as one of the world's most significant public health challenges, particularly in low-and middle-income countries.

10  According to WHO, as many as 36.9 million people were living with HIV globally, in 2014, and of these, 2.6 million were children.

11  An estimated 2.6 million children are living with HIV in sub-Saharan Africa.

12  HIV is the strongest risk factor for developing active T.B. disease.

How well do you know the difference between HIV and AIDS?

HIV stands for Human Immunodeficiency Virus infection and AIDS stands for Acquired Immuno Deficiency syndrome. HIV is a virus that may cause an infection, while AIDS is a condition or a syndrome.

HIV infection can lead to having AIDS which can cause serious damage to the immune system.
